# Refined Solution
### Problem Statement Explanation
- We consider motion in an inertial ground frame S along the x axis.
- Two trains, A and B, each have intrinsic (proper) length L0 when at rest.
- Initial positions at t = 0 in S:
  - Left end of train A is at x = 0; therefore, the right end of A is at x = L0.
  - The gap between the right end of A and the left end of B is D, so the left end of B is at x = L0 + D.
- At t = 0 (S-time), both trains start accelerating from rest. The clocks located at the left ends of both trains are set to zero at that instant: t_A = t_B = 0.
- “Constant accelerations relative to themselves” is interpreted as: the left end of each train undergoes constant proper acceleration (i.e., constant in its own instantaneous rest frame), with magnitudes a_A for train A’s left end and a_B for train B’s left end. Each train is assumed to be Born rigid, so that in the instantaneous rest frame of the left end the proper separation to the right end remains L0. This implies non-uniform proper acceleration along each train, determined by the left-end value.
- Define D(t) in frame S as the instantaneous separation between the left end of train B and the right end of train A:
  - D(t) = x_lB(t) − x_rA(t)
- Requirement: D(t) ≡ D for all t ≥ 0.
- Goal: Express a_B in terms of L0, a_A, and c such that D(t) remains constant.

### Step 1
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{d\tau = \frac{dt}{\gamma},\quad \gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - v^{2}/c^{2}}}}\]
\[\boxed{a_{\text{proper}} = \gamma^{3}\,\frac{dv}{dt}\quad\text{(1D motion)}}\]
\[\boxed{v(\tau) = c\,\tanh\!\left(\frac{a\,\tau}{c}\right),\quad \gamma(\tau) = \cosh\!\left(\frac{a\,\tau}{c}\right)}\]
\[\boxed{t(\tau) = \frac{c}{a}\,\sinh\!\left(\frac{a\,\tau}{c}\right),\quad x(\tau) = \frac{c^{2}}{a}\Big[\cosh\!\left(\frac{a\,\tau}{c}\right) - 1\Big]}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{For constant proper acceleration } a: \quad a_{\text{proper}}=\gamma^{3}\frac{dv}{dt} \Rightarrow \frac{dv}{dt}=a\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right)^{3/2}. \label{eq:dvdt} \tag{1}\\
&\frac{dv}{d\tau}=\frac{dv}{dt}\frac{dt}{d\tau}=\frac{a}{\gamma^{3}}\gamma=\frac{a}{\gamma^{2}}=a\left(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\right). \label{eq:dvdtau} \tag{2}\\
&\text{Integrating \eqref{eq:dvdtau} with } v(0)=0: \quad \operatorname{artanh}\!\left(\frac{v}{c}\right)=\frac{a\tau}{c} \\
&\Rightarrow v(\tau)=c\tanh\!\left(\frac{a\tau}{c}\right),\ \ \gamma(\tau)=\cosh\!\left(\frac{a\tau}{c}\right). \label{eq:v_gamma_tau} \tag{3}\\
&\frac{dt}{d\tau}=\gamma=\cosh\!\left(\frac{a\tau}{c}\right)\Rightarrow t(\tau)=\frac{c}{a}\sinh\!\left(\frac{a\tau}{c}\right). \label{eq:t_tau} \tag{4}\\
&\frac{dx}{d\tau}=\gamma v=c\,\sinh\!\left(\frac{a\tau}{c}\right)\Rightarrow x(\tau)=\frac{c^{2}}{a}\Big[\cosh\!\left(\frac{a\tau}{c}\right)-1\Big]. \label{eq:x_tau} \tag{5}\\
&\text{Eliminating }\tau:\ \sinh\!\left(\frac{a\tau}{c}\right)=\frac{a t}{c},\ \cosh=\sqrt{1+\sinh^{2}} \Rightarrow \\
&v(t)=\frac{a t}{\sqrt{1+(a t/c)^{2}}},\quad x(t)=\frac{c^{2}}{a}\left(\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right). \label{eq:vx_t} \tag{6}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 2
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\text{Worldline in S for a particle with constant proper acceleration }a\text{ starting from rest at }x_0: \ x(t)=x_{0}+\frac{c^{2}}{a}\Big(\sqrt{1+(a t/c)^{2}}-1\Big)}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{Left end of A starts at }x=0: \quad x_{lA}(t)=\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}\!\left(\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{A} t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right). \label{eq:x_lA} \tag{7}\\
&\text{Left end of B starts at }x=L_{0}+D: \quad x_{lB}(t)=L_{0}+D+\frac{c^{2}}{a_{B}}\!\left(\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{B} t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right). \label{eq:x_lB} \tag{8}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 3
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\Delta t = \gamma\left(\Delta t' + \frac{v\,\Delta x'}{c^{2}}\right),\quad \Delta x = \gamma\left(\Delta x' + v\,\Delta t'\right)\ \ \text{(Lorentz transformation of separations)}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Born rigidity: in the instantaneous rest frame of the left end, the right end is at }(\Delta x',\Delta t')=(L_{0},0)}\]
\[\boxed{t(\tau)=\frac{c}{a}\sinh\!\left(\frac{a\,\tau}{c}\right),\ \ x(\tau)=\frac{c^{2}}{a}\Big[\cosh\!\left(\frac{a\,\tau}{c}\right)-1\Big],\ \ v(\tau)=c\tanh\!\left(\frac{a\tau}{c}\right),\ \ \gamma(\tau)=\cosh\!\left(\frac{a\tau}{c}\right)}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{For A’s left end at proper time }\tau:\ t_{lA}=\frac{c}{a_{A}}\sinh\!\left(\frac{a_{A}\tau}{c}\right),\ \ x_{lA}=\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}\!\left[\cosh\!\left(\frac{a_{A}\tau}{c}\right)-1\right], \\
&v_{A}(\tau)=c\tanh\!\left(\frac{a_{A}\tau}{c}\right),\ \gamma_{A}(\tau)=\cosh\!\left(\frac{a_{A}\tau}{c}\right). \label{eq:A_left_param} \tag{9}\\
&\text{In the left-end instantaneous rest frame, the right end is }(\Delta x',\Delta t')=(L_{0},0). \\
&\text{Transform to S: } \Delta t=\gamma_{A}\frac{v_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}},\ \Delta x=\gamma_{A}L_{0}. \label{eq:lorentz_sep} \tag{10}\\
&\Rightarrow t_{rA}(\tau)=t_{lA}+\gamma_{A}\frac{v_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}=\frac{c}{a_{A}}\sinh\!\left(\frac{a_{A}\tau}{c}\right)+\frac{L_{0}}{c}\sinh\!\left(\frac{a_{A}\tau}{c}\right) \\
&\qquad\qquad\quad = \left(1+\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}\right)t_{lA}(\tau). \label{eq:t_rA_tau} \tag{11}\\
&x_{rA}(\tau)=x_{lA}+\gamma_{A}L_{0}=\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}\!\left[\cosh\!\left(\frac{a_{A}\tau}{c}\right)-1\right]+L_{0}\cosh\!\left(\frac{a_{A}\tau}{c}\right). \label{eq:x_rA_tau} \tag{12}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 4
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\cosh u=\sqrt{1+\sinh^{2}u},\quad \sinh u=\frac{a\,t}{c}\ \text{ when }t=\frac{c}{a}\sinh u}\]
\[\boxed{a_{R}\equiv \frac{a_{A}}{1+\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}\quad\text{(proper acceleration of A’s right end under Born-rigid motion)}}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{From \eqref{eq:t_rA_tau}: } t_{lA}(\tau) = \frac{t_{rA}}{1+\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}. \label{eq:tl_from_tr} \tag{13}\\
&\text{Let } u \equiv \frac{a_{A}\tau}{c}. \ \text{Then } \sinh u = \frac{a_{A} t_{lA}}{c} = \frac{a_{A}}{c}\cdot \frac{t_{rA}}{1+\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}} = \frac{a_{R} t_{rA}}{c}. \label{eq:sinh_u} \tag{14}\\
&\Rightarrow \cosh u = \sqrt{1+\sinh^{2}u} = \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{R} t_{rA}}{c}\right)^{2}}. \label{eq:cosh_u} \tag{15}\\
&\text{Insert \eqref{eq:cosh_u} into \eqref{eq:x_rA_tau} and set }t\equiv t_{rA}: \\
&x_{rA}(t) = \frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}\left[\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{R} t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right] + L_{0}\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{R} t}{c}\right)^{2}} \\
&\qquad\ \ = -\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}} + \left(\frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}+L_{0}\right)\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{R} t}{c}\right)^{2}}. \label{eq:x_rA_t_intermediate} \tag{16}\\
&\text{Since } \frac{1}{a_{R}} = \frac{1}{a_{A}}\Big(1+\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}\Big) \Rightarrow \frac{c^{2}}{a_{A}}+L_{0}=\frac{c^{2}}{a_{R}}, \text{ we obtain} \label{eq:identity} \tag{17}\\
&x_{rA}(t) = L_{0} + \frac{c^{2}}{a_{R}}\left[\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{R} t}{c}\right)^{2}} - 1\right]. \label{eq:x_rA_finalform} \tag{18}
\end{align}
\]
Thus the right end of A moves as a uniformly (properly) accelerated point starting from x = L0 at t = 0 with proper acceleration a_R.

### Step 5
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{D(t) = x_{lB}(t) - x_{rA}(t)}\]
\[\boxed{\text{For fixed }t>0,\ f(a)\equiv \frac{c^{2}}{a}\Big(\sqrt{1+(a t/c)^{2}}-1\Big)\ \text{is strictly increasing in }a>0}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&D(t) = \Big[L_{0}+D+\frac{c^{2}}{a_{B}}\big(\sqrt{1+(\tfrac{a_{B} t}{c})^{2}}-1\big)\Big] - \Big[L_{0}+\frac{c^{2}}{a_{R}}\big(\sqrt{1+(\tfrac{a_{R} t}{c})^{2}}-1\big)\Big] \\
&\qquad = D + \frac{c^{2}}{a_{B}}\left[\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{B} t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right] - \frac{c^{2}}{a_{R}}\left[\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{R} t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right]. \label{eq:D_t} \tag{19}\\
&\text{Impose }D(t)\equiv D\ \forall t\ge 0:\ \frac{c^{2}}{a_{B}}\left[\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{B} t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right] = \frac{c^{2}}{a_{R}}\left[\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{a_{R} t}{c}\right)^{2}}-1\right]\ \forall t. \label{eq:fa_eq} \tag{20}\\
&\text{Define for fixed }t>0:\ f(a)=\frac{c^{2}}{a}\Big(\sqrt{1+(a t/c)^{2}}-1\Big). \\
&\text{Let }\alpha=\frac{a t}{c}>0 \Rightarrow f(a)=\frac{c t}{\alpha}\big(\sqrt{1+\alpha^{2}}-1\big)=c t\,g(\alpha),\ \ g(\alpha)=\frac{\sqrt{1+\alpha^{2}}-1}{\alpha}. \label{eq:fa_ga} \tag{21}\\
&\text{Rationalize }g:\ g(\alpha)=\frac{(1+\alpha^{2})-1}{\alpha\left(\sqrt{1+\alpha^{2}}+1\right)}=\frac{\alpha}{\sqrt{1+\alpha^{2}}+1}. \label{eq:g_rationalized} \tag{22}\\
&\text{Hence } g'(\alpha)=\frac{(\sqrt{1+\alpha^{2}}+1)-\alpha\cdot\frac{\alpha}{\sqrt{1+\alpha^{2}}}}{(\sqrt{1+\alpha^{2}}+1)^{2}}=\frac{1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\alpha^{2}}}}{(\sqrt{1+\alpha^{2}}+1)^{2}}>0 \\
&\text{for all }\alpha>0. \ \Rightarrow g\ \text{strictly increases in }\alpha,\ \text{so } f\ \text{strictly increases in }a. \label{eq:monotone} \tag{23}\\
&\text{Therefore, equality } f(a_{B})=f(a_{R})\ \forall t>0 \ \Rightarrow\ a_{B}=a_{R}. \label{eq:uniqueness} \tag{24}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 6
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{a_{R}=\frac{a_{A}}{1+\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{From \eqref{eq:uniqueness}},\ a_{B}=a_{R}\ \Rightarrow\ a_{B}=\frac{a_{A}}{1+\frac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}. \label{eq:final} \tag{25}
\end{align}
\]

### Final Answer
\[
\begin{align}
a_{B}=\frac{a_{A}}{1+\dfrac{a_{A}L_{0}}{c^{2}}}
\end{align}
\]

questions: Two smooth cylinders, each with a radius of $r_{1}$ but with weights $P_{1}$ and $P_{2}$ respectively, are placed in a smooth cylindrical groove with a radius of $R$. Find the tangent value of the angle $\varphi$ when the two cylinders are in equilibrium. The angle $\varphi$ is defined as the angle between the line connecting the center of the higher cylinder and the center of the cylindrical groove, and the horizontal line. Assume $\cos\beta = \frac{r}{R - r}$. Express the result in terms of $\beta$.
solutions:
Under the action of these forces, cylinders 1 and 2 reach equilibrium. Triangle \( O O_{1}O_{2} \) is an isosceles triangle. Let \(\beta=\angle O O_{1}O_{2},\) then  

\[ 
\cos \beta = \frac{r}{R-r}.
\]

For cylinder 1, the condition for force equilibrium is  

\[ 
\begin{array}{r l}
&{P_{1}+f\sin(\beta-\varphi)-N_{1}\sin(2\beta-\varphi)=0,}\\
&{f\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{1}\cos(2\beta-\varphi)=0.}
\end{array}
\]

By eliminating \( N_{1} \) from the two equations in expression (2), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{1}\cos(2\beta-\varphi)-f\sin\beta=0.
\]

Eliminating \( f \), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{1}\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{1}\sin\beta=0.
\]

For cylinder 2, at equilibrium we have  

\[ 
\begin{array}{r l}
&{P_{2}-f\sin(\beta-\varphi)-N_{2}\sin\varphi=0,}\\
&{f\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{2}\cos\varphi=0.}
\end{array}
\]

By eliminating \( N_{2} \) from the two equations in expression (5), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{2}\cos\varphi-f\sin\beta=0.
\]

Eliminating \( f \), we obtain  

\[ 
P_{2}\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_{2}\sin\beta=0.
\]

By eliminating \( f \) from equations (3) and (6), we obtain  

\[ 
\tan\varphi = \frac{P_{2}-P_{1}\cos(2\beta)}{P_{1}\sin(2\beta)}.
\]

This is the relationship that \(\varphi\) satisfies when the system is at equilibrium.

# Refined Solution
### Problem Statement Explanation
We consider two smooth (frictionless) small cylinders, each of radius r1 (denote r ≡ r1), but with different weights (gravitational forces) P1 and P2, placed inside a smooth cylindrical groove of radius R. The three centers (groove center and the two cylinder centers) lie in the same plane.

Definitions and geometry:
- Let O be the center of the groove, and O1, O2 be the centers of the upper and lower small cylinders, respectively.
- Because each small cylinder touches the groove, OO1 = OO2 = R − r. Because the two small cylinders touch each other, O1O2 = 2r. Thus triangle OO1O2 is isosceles with equal sides R − r and base 2r.
- The angle φ is defined as the angle between the horizontal and the line OO1 (from O to the upper cylinder’s center).
- We are given the geometric parameter β via cos β = r/(R − r). In triangle OO1O2, the base angles are β and the apex angle at O is π − 2β. This is consistent since the chord length O1O2 = 2(R − r) sin[(π − 2β)/2] = 2(R − r) cos β = 2r.
- All contacts are smooth; hence every contact force acts along the common normal (line of centers at the contact).

Forces:
- On cylinder 1 (upper): weight P1 downward; groove reaction N1 along O1O (collinear with OO1 but opposite direction); mutual normal contact f along O1O2.
- On cylinder 2 (lower): weight P2 downward; groove reaction N2 along O2O; mutual normal contact f along O1O2 (equal magnitude, opposite direction to that on cylinder 1).

We choose a fixed Cartesian frame with +x horizontal to the right and +y upward. The goal is to find tan φ in terms of P1, P2, and β.

### Step 1
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{\cos\beta=\frac{r}{R-r}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{In triangle }OO_1O_2:\ OO_1=OO_2=R-r,\ O_1O_2=2r,\ \angle OO_1O_2=\angle OO_2O_1=\beta,\ \angle O=\pi-2\beta}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Frictionless contact: normal reaction acts along the common normal (line of centers).}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Static equilibrium for a particle (planar): }\sum F_x=0,\ \sum F_y=0}\]

Derivation:
We record directions needed for component resolution:
- OO1 makes angle φ with +x; O1O (direction of N1 on cylinder 1) thus makes angle φ+π.
- The central angle between OO1 and OO2 is π−2β; therefore OO2 makes angle φ−(π−2β) with +x, and O2O (direction of N2 on cylinder 2) makes angle φ+2β.
- At O1, the angle between O1O and O1O2 equals the base angle β; hence the line O1O2 is rotated by β from O1O. Correspondingly, force f on cylinder 1 acts along O1O2, and on cylinder 2 in the opposite direction. These relations fix the direction cosines used below.
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{Set up the angular references for }N_1,\ N_2,\ f,\ \text{and the weights for use in equilibrium equations.}
\label{eq:geom} \tag{1}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 2
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{\text{Cylinder 1 equilibrium (components): }\sum F_x=0,\ \sum F_y=0}\]
\[\boxed{\cos(A\pm B)=\cos A\cos B\mp\sin A\sin B,\quad \sin(A\pm B)=\sin A\cos B\pm\cos A\sin B}\]
\[\boxed{\tan\theta=\dfrac{\sin\theta}{\cos\theta}}\]

Derivation:
For cylinder 1, forces: P1 downward, N1 along O1O, f along O1O2. Resolving (using the geometric orientations summarized in (1)) yields two linear equations in N1 and f:
\[
\begin{align}
& f\cos(\beta-\varphi)-N_1\cos(2\beta-\varphi)=0,
\label{eq:1x} \tag{2a}\\
& -P_1+f\sin(\beta-\varphi)-N_1\sin(2\beta-\varphi)=0.
\label{eq:1y} \tag{2b}
\end{align}
\]
From \eqref{eq:1x}, N1=\dfrac{f\cos(\beta-\varphi)}{\cos(2\beta-\varphi)}. Substitute into \eqref{eq:1y}:
\[
\begin{align}
-P_1+f\sin(\beta-\varphi)-\frac{f\cos(\beta-\varphi)}{\cos(2\beta-\varphi)}\sin(2\beta-\varphi)=0
\ \Longrightarrow\
-P_1+f\Big[\sin(\beta-\varphi)-\cos(\beta-\varphi)\tan(2\beta-\varphi)\Big]=0.
\label{eq:1ysub} \tag{3}
\end{align}
\]
Using
\[
\sin x-\cos x\,\tan y=\frac{\sin x\cos y-\cos x\sin y}{\cos y}=\frac{\sin(x-y)}{\cos y},
\]
with x=\beta-\varphi,\ y=2\beta-\varphi, we get x-y=-\beta and hence
\[
\sin(\beta-\varphi)-\cos(\beta-\varphi)\tan(2\beta-\varphi)=-\frac{\sin\beta}{\cos(2\beta-\varphi)}.
\]
Thus,
\[
\begin{align}
-P_1-\frac{f\sin\beta}{\cos(2\beta-\varphi)}=0
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
P_1\cos(2\beta-\varphi)+f\sin\beta=0.
\label{eq:key1} \tag{4}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 3
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{\text{Cylinder 2 equilibrium (components): }\sum F_x=0,\ \sum F_y=0}\]
\[\boxed{\sin(A+B)=\sin A\cos B+\cos A\sin B,\quad \cos(A+B)=\cos A\cos B-\sin A\sin B}\]
\[\boxed{\sin(\beta-\varphi)+\cos(\beta-\varphi)\tan\varphi=\dfrac{\sin\beta}{\cos\varphi}}\]

Derivation:

From \eqref{eq:2x}, N2=\dfrac{f\cos(\beta-\varphi)}{\cos\varphi}. Substitute into \eqref{eq:2y}:

so

The plane formed by the rods and strings is perpendicular to the tabletop, with gravitational acceleration $g$. Initially, the rods are stationary, forming an angle $\theta_{0}$ with the tabletop. What is the magnitude of the velocity $v$ of the rods just before the ends connected at the table touch the tabletop?

Initial mechanical energy: $\frac{1}{2}mgl\sin\theta_{0}$ 
Mechanical energy while in motion (angular velocity is $\dot{\theta}$): translational kinetic energy $^{+}$ rotational kinetic energy $^+$ gravitational potential energy:
$$
{\frac{1}{2}}m{\dot{\theta}}^{2}{\frac{l^{2}}{4}}+{\frac{1}{2}}{\frac{1}{12}}m l^{2}{\dot{\theta}}^{2}+{\frac{1}{2}}m g l \sin\theta={\frac{1}{6}}m l^{2}{\dot{\theta}}^{2}+{\frac{1}{2}}m g l \sin\theta

# Refined Solution
### Problem Statement Explanation
We consider two identical thin rods, each of mass m and length l, lying in a vertical plane that is perpendicular to a horizontal tabletop. The lower end of each rod rests on the tabletop and is free to slide without friction. The upper ends of the two rods are tied together by a very short, flexible, massless string, so that the two upper ends coincide at a single common point (a hinge-like connection). Initially, a thin, massless string connects the midpoints of the two rods and holds them at rest with each rod making an angle θ0 with the tabletop. Then the central string is cut; the rods move under gravity with acceleration g until they reach the table (θ → 0+). We are asked for the magnitude v of the velocity of the rods just before the instant when the upper connected ends touch the tabletop (i.e., the speed of the common upper point just before contact).

Definitions and assumptions:
- θ(t): instantaneous angle that each rod makes with the horizontal tabletop; θ(0) = θ0 and θ → 0+ at contact.
- Due to symmetry, the common upper point moves vertically (its horizontal coordinate remains constant).
- The lower ends move horizontally without friction and remain at height y = 0 at all times.
- The height of the common upper point above the tabletop is y_top = l sin θ.
- For each rod, the center of mass (COM) is at its midpoint: coordinates (±(l/2) cos θ, (l/2) sin θ), with the ± corresponding to the two symmetric rods.
- The tabletop is frictionless, strings are massless, and no nonconservative work is done by constraints, so mechanical energy of the two-rod system is conserved.

### Step 1
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{\text{By symmetry, the common upper point moves vertically; its horizontal coordinate is constant.}}\]
\[\boxed{y_{\text{top}}(t)=l\,\sin\theta(t)}\]
\[\boxed{(x_c,y_c)=\left(\pm\frac{l}{2}\cos\theta,\ \frac{l}{2}\sin\theta\right)\ \text{(COM of each rod)}}\]
\[\boxed{\frac{d}{dt}\sin\theta=\cos\theta\,\dot\theta,\quad \frac{d}{dt}\cos\theta=-\sin\theta\,\dot\theta}\]

Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
y_{\text{top}}(t)&=l\sin\theta(t)
\label{eq:y_top} \tag{1}\\
x_c(t)&=\pm\frac{l}{2}\cos\theta(t),\qquad y_c(t)=\frac{l}{2}\sin\theta(t)
\label{eq:com_coords} \tag{2}\\
\dot x_c&=\mp\frac{l}{2}\sin\theta\,\dot\theta,\qquad \dot y_c=\frac{l}{2}\cos\theta\,\dot\theta
\label{eq:com_vel_components} \tag{3}\\
v_c^2&=\dot x_c^2+\dot y_c^2=\left(\frac{l}{2}\right)^2\left(\sin^2\theta+\cos^2\theta\right)\dot\theta^2=\left(\frac{l}{2}\right)^2\dot\theta^2
\label{eq:vc_sq} \tag{4}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 2
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{T=\frac{1}{2}m v_{\text{cm}}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}I_{\text{cm}}\omega^{2}}\]
\[\boxed{I_{\text{cm}}=\frac{1}{12}ml^{2}\ \text{ for a slender rod about its center}}\]
\[\boxed{\omega=\dot\theta}\]

Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
T_{\text{one rod}}&=\frac{1}{2}m v_c^2+\frac{1}{2}I_{\text{cm}}\omega^2
=\frac{1}{2}m\left(\frac{l^2}{4}\dot\theta^2\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{12}ml^2\right)\dot\theta^2
\label{eq:T_one_expand} \tag{5}\\
&=\left(\frac{1}{8}+\frac{1}{24}\right)ml^2\dot\theta^2=\frac{1}{6}ml^2\dot\theta^2
\label{eq:T_one} \tag{6}\\
T_{\text{total}}&=2\,T_{\text{one rod}}=\frac{1}{3}ml^2\dot\theta^2
\label{eq:T_total} \tag{7}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 3
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{V=mg\,y\quad\text{(gravitational potential energy at height }y)}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Reference level: }V=0\text{ at the tabletop }(y=0).}\]

Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
V_{\text{one rod}}&=m g\,y_c = m g\left(\frac{l}{2}\sin\theta\right)=\frac{1}{2}mgl\sin\theta
\label{eq:V_one} \tag{8}\\
V_{\text{total}}&=2\,V_{\text{one rod}}=mgl\sin\theta
\label{eq:V_total} \tag{9}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 4
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{E_{\text{mech}}=T+V=\text{constant (no nonconservative work)}}\]
\[\boxed{W_{\text{constraint}}=\int \mathbf{F}_{\text{constraint}}\cdot \mathbf{v}_{\text{point}}\,dt=0\ \text{(here: no friction; normal acts where }v_n=0)}\]
\[\boxed{\theta(0)=\theta_0,\ \dot\theta(0)=0}\]

Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
E_{\text{initial}}&=T(0)+V(0)=0+mgl\sin\theta_0
\label{eq:E_init} \tag{10}\\
E_{\text{instant}}&=T+V=\frac{1}{3}ml^2\dot\theta^2+mgl\sin\theta
\label{eq:E_inst} \tag{11}\\
E_{\text{instant}}&=E_{\text{initial}}
\ \Rightarrow\ \frac{1}{3}ml^2\dot\theta^2+mgl\sin\theta=mgl\sin\theta_0
\label{eq:cons_energy} \tag{12}\\
\dot\theta^2&=\frac{3g}{l}\,\bigl(\sin\theta_0-\sin\theta\bigr)
\label{eq:theta_dot_sq} \tag{13}
\end{align}
\]

Justification of zero work by constraints: The table is frictionless, so no tangential (horizontal) force acts at the lower ends. The normal force is vertical, but the lower end points have zero vertical velocity (they remain at y=0), hence the power N·v_vertical = 0. The upper connection is internal to the two-rod system at a single common point; internal forces at the same point do no net work on the system. Therefore, mechanical energy is conserved.

### Step 5
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{v_{\text{top}}=\left|\dot y_{\text{top}}\right|=\left|\frac{d}{dt}\bigl(l\sin\theta\bigr)\right|=l\,|\cos\theta|\,|\dot\theta|}\]

Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
v_{\text{top}}(\theta)&=l\,|\cos\theta|\,\sqrt{\frac{3g}{l}\,\bigl(\sin\theta_0-\sin\theta\bigr)}
\label{eq:v_top_theta} \tag{14}\\
\lim_{\theta\to 0^{+}} v_{\text{top}}(\theta)&=l\cdot 1\cdot \sqrt{\frac{3g}{l}\,\sin\theta_0}
=\sqrt{3gl\,\sin\theta_0}
\label{eq:v_top_final} \tag{15}
\end{align}
\]

Thus, the magnitude of the velocity of the rods (i.e., of the common upper point where the ends are connected) just before they touch the tabletop is as given below.

### Final Answer
\[
\begin{align}
\boxed{v=\sqrt{3\,g\,l\,\sin\theta_{0}}}
\end{align}
\]

questions:
An arbitrary multi-terminal resistor network structure, for example with $N+1$ terminals, sets one specific terminal (0 terminal) as the reference for electric potential, setting its potential at 0. The potentials for other terminals (numbered 1, 2, ..., N) are $v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots, v_{N}$, and the current flowing into the network through these corresponding terminals (negative when flowing out) are $I_{1}, I_2, \ldots, I_n$. Therefore, we have:

$$
\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
V_{1} = a_{11} I_{1} + a_{12} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{1N} I_{N} \\
V_{2} = a_{21} I_{1} + a_{22} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{2N} I_{N} \\
\vdots \\
V_{i} = a_{i1} I_{1} + a_{i2} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{iN} I_{N} \\
\vdots \\
V_{N} = a_{N1} I_{1} + a_{N2} I_{2} + \cdots + a_{NN} I_{N} 
\end{array}
\right.
$$

Due to symmetry, we know that $a_{ij} = a_{ji}$.

This means that the properties of the $N+1$ terminal network can be determined by $\frac{N(N+1)}{2}$ independent parameters: $a_{11}, a_{12}, \ldots , a_{ij}, \ldots , a_{NN} (i<j)$. These parameters are only determined by the resistor network itself and are unrelated to the potential at the terminals or the magnitude of the current flowing in.

Consider a square uniform conductive thin plate as a four-terminal resistor network. The four vertices are sequentially numbered clockwise as 0, 1, 2, 3. If the equivalent resistance between adjacent vertices is ${R}_{1}$ and the equivalent resistance between opposite vertices is ${{R}}_{2}$, use the method of finding the coefficients $a_{i j} (i,j=1,2,3)$ to solve: what is the equivalent resistance between the other two vertices if a pair of adjacent vertices is short-circuited?
solutions:
For this situation, label the 4 endpoints sequentially as 0, 1, 2, 3. If current flows into endpoint 1 with current I (flowing out from endpoint 0), then:   

$$
V_{1}=a_{11}I=I R_{1}
$$  

Thus, we obtain: $a_{11}=R_{1}$  

Similarly, if current flows into endpoints 2 or 3 with current I, we can respectively obtain: $a_{22}=R_{2}$ $a_{33}=R_{1}$. If current flows into endpoint 1 with current I and flows out from endpoint 2:  

$$
V_{1}^{\prime}=a_{11}I-a_{12}I,V_{2}^{\prime}=a_{21}I-a_{22}I
$$  

At this moment, the potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2 is:  

$$
V_{1}^{\prime}-V_{2}^{\prime}=(a_{11}-2a_{12}+a_{22})I
$$  

Due to symmetry, at this moment, the potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2 should be equal to the potential at endpoint 1 (between 1 and 0) when current flows only into endpoint 1 (out from endpoint 0), thus:  

$$
(a_{11}-2a_{12}+a_{22})I=a_{11}I
$$  

We obtain:  

$$
a_{12}=\frac{1}{2}a_{22}=\frac{1}{2}R_{2}
$$  

[This can also be directly obtained by the condition of current input into endpoint 2, where the potential at endpoint 1 is half of that at endpoint 2 due to symmetry.] Similarly, we obtain:  

$$
a_{23}=\frac{1}{2}R_{2}
$$  

Returning again to the situation with current flowing only into endpoint 1 (flowing out from endpoint 0), at this moment, the potentials at endpoints 2 and 3 are respectively:  

$$
V_{2}=a_{21}I,V_{3}=a_{31}I
$$  

Due to symmetry, the potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2 should be equal to the potential difference between endpoints 3 and 0, thus:  

$$
V_{1}-V_{2}=V_{3}
$$  

Therefore:  

$$
a_{11}I-a_{21}I=a_{31}I
$$  

We obtain:  

$$
a_{13}=a_{31}=a_{11}-a_{12}=R_{1}-{\frac{1}{2}}R_{2}
$$  

Now returning to the required situation of the problem, without loss of generality, we can assume endpoints 3 and 0 are short-circuited and calculate the equivalent resistance between endpoints 1 and 2. In this case, if current flows into endpoint 1 with current I and out from endpoint 2, since endpoints 3 and 0 are short-circuited, there must be current flowing from 0 through the short-circuit wire into endpoint 3. Let the current flowing through the short-circuit wire be $I^{\prime}$, then it can be considered as the original four-terminal situation with current flowing into endpoint 1, out from endpoint 2, and into endpoint 3 with $I^{\prime}$. At this moment, the potential at endpoint 3 is:  

$$
V_{3}=a_{31}I-a_{32}I+a_{33}I^{\prime}
$$  

Because 3 and 0 are practically short-circuited, $V_{3}$ should be 0. Thus we can compute:  

$$
I^{\prime}=\frac{a_{32}-a_{31}}{a_{33}}I=\frac{R_{2}-R_{1}}{R_{1}}I
$$  

We can then compute the potentials at endpoints 1 and 2:  

The potential difference between endpoints 1 and 2:  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{V_{1}=a_{11}I-a_{12}I+a_{13}I^{\prime}=(R_{1}-\displaystyle{\frac{1}{2}}R_{2})\displaystyle{\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}}I}}\ {{V_{2}=a_{21}I-a_{22}I+a_{23}I^{\prime}=\displaystyle{\frac{R_{2}}{2}}\displaystyle{\frac{R_{2}-2R_{1}}{R_{1}}}I}}\end{array}
$$  

$$
V_{1}-V_{2}=\frac{(2R_{1}-R_{2})R_{2}}{2R_{1}}I
$$  

Thus, the equivalent resistance between endpoints 1 and 2 is:  

$$
R={\frac{V_{1}-V_{2}}{I}}={\frac{(2R_{1}-R_{2})R_{2}}{2R_{1}}}=(2-{\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}})R_{2}
$$

questions: Consider a semi-infinite solenoid with radius $R$, turns per unit length $n$, connected to a constant current source with current $I$. To facilitate subsequent calculations, we establish a cylindrical coordinate system such that the $z$-axis coincides with the symmetry axis of the solenoid. The solenoid extends from the origin along the negative $z$-axis to infinity, and the current is viewed as rotating counterclockwise when observed from above the $z$-axis, meaning the direction of the current is in the positive $\hat{\theta}$ direction. Now, a superconducting metal ring is placed such that some constraint keeps the symmetry axis of the current loop always coinciding with the $z$-axis, allowing it to move freely up and down in this state. It is known that at the instant the metal ring transitions from normal to superconducting state, a current $I_{0}$ flows within the ring, and there is no other external magnetic field at a sufficiently far distance from the solenoid. $I_{0}$ flows in the positive $\hat{\theta}$ direction. Subsequently, the metal ring remains in the superconducting state. Assume the gravitational acceleration is $\overrightarrow{g}=-g\widehat{z}$, the mass of the metal ring is $m$, and it is of uniform density. Let $z_{0}>0$ be known. If the equilibrium is stable, find the vibration period $T$ near the equilibrium position (expressed in terms of $n$, $I_{0}$, $r$, $R$, $L$, $m$), and the answer may include $z_{0}$. It is known that the radius of the metal ring is $r \ll R$, and the self-inductance is $L$.
solutions:
The equilibrium condition is

$$
F(z)=m g
$$

$$
\frac{\pi}{2}\mu_{0}n I R^{2}r^{2}\frac{1}{(z^{2}+R^{2})^{3/2}}(\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}(1-\frac{z}{\sqrt{z^{2}+R^{2}}})-I_{0})=m g
$$

Consider the stability of the equilibrium. If $\frac{d F}{d z}$ is negative, then the equilibrium is stable; otherwise, it is unstable.

$$
\left.{\frac{d F}{d z}}\right|_{z_{0}}={\frac{\pi}{2}}\mu_{0}n I R^{2}r^{2}\cdot[({\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}}-I_{0}){\frac{-3z_{0}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{5/2}}}+{\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}}{\frac{3z_{0}^{2}-R^{2}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{3}}}]
$$

Therefore, the requirement for stability is

$$
\frac{3z_{0}^{2}-R^{2}}{3z_{0}\sqrt{z_{0}^{2}+R^{2}}}<1-\frac{2I_{0}L}{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}
$$

If the equilibrium is stable, then

$$
T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m}{\left.\displaystyle-\frac{d F}{d z}\right|_{z_{0}}}}
$$

$$
T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m}{\frac{\pi}{2}\mu_{0}n I R^{2}r^{2}\cdot[(\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}-I_{0})\frac{3z_{0}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{5/2}}-\frac{\mu_{0}n I\pi r^{2}}{2L}\frac{3z_{0}^{2}-R^{2}}{(z_{0}^{2}+R^{2})^{3}}]}}
$$

questions: Two dielectric materials with base areas both equal to $\pmb{A}$, thicknesses of $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ respectively, dielectric constants of $\varepsilon_{1}$ and $\varepsilon_{2}$ respectively, and conductivities of $\sigma_{1}$ and $\sigma_{2}$ respectively, are placed tightly between two highly conductive flat plates with the same area $\pmb{A}$ and a separation distance of $(h_{1}+h_{2})$, forming a capacitor. The system is connected into a circuit , with a power source of electromotive force $U_{0}$. Initially, the capacitor is uncharged, and at $\scriptstyle t=0$, the switch is turned on. Determine the time-dependent relationship of the current $I(t)$ flowing through the switch for $t > 0$.
solutions:
Let the magnitudes of the electric field intensity in the two media be $E_{1}, E_{2}$ respectively, and according to the relationship between the electric potentials, we have  

$$
E_{1}h_{1} + E_{2}h_{2} = U_{0}
$$  

The magnitudes of the current density in the two media are  

$$
\begin{aligned}
    j_1 &= \sigma_1 E_1, \\
    j_2 &= \sigma_2 E_2.
\end{aligned}
$$  

Let the free charge surface density at the contact of the two media be $\sigma_{\bullet}$, then  

From this, we obtain  

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l l}{\displaystyle{\frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma_{\circ}}{\mathrm{d}t}}=j_{1}-j_{2}}\ {\sigma_{\circ}=\varepsilon_{2}E_{2}-\varepsilon_{1}E_{1}}\end{array}\right.
$$  

$$
U_{0} = \frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma_{0}}{\mathrm{d}t}\cdot\left(\frac{h_{1}\varepsilon_{2} + h_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}{\sigma_{1}\varepsilon_{2} - \sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}\right) + \sigma_{0}\cdot\left(\frac{\sigma_{1}h_{2} + \sigma_{2}h_{1}}{\sigma_{1}\varepsilon_{2} - \sigma_{2}\varepsilon_{1}}\right)

That is  

$$

$$  

The current in the circuit can be obtained as  

$$
I = A{\left(\sigma_{1}E_{1} + \varepsilon_{1}{\frac{\mathrm{d}E_{1}}{\mathrm{d}t}}\right)} = A{\left(\sigma_{2}E_{2} + \varepsilon_{2}{\frac{\mathrm{d}E_{2}}{\mathrm{d}t}}\right)}

$$

For the collision process between the square block and the snow, consider the conservation of momentum:  $$ M v = (M + \sigma\gamma u{\mathrm{d}}t)(v - {\mathrm{d}}v) $$  This results in:  $$ \mathrm{d}\upsilon = -\frac{\sigma r v^{2}}{M}\mathrm{d}t $$  The energy loss during the process is:  $$ d E = \frac{1}{2}(M + \mathrm{d}M)(\upsilon + \mathrm{d}\upsilon)^{2} - \frac{1}{2}(M)\upsilon^{2} = -\frac{1}{2}\sigma r\upsilon^{2}\upsilon\mathrm{d}t = -\frac{1}{2}\sigma r\upsilon^{2}\mathrm{d}s $$  In this case, it can be treated as linear motion, and the equation is not influenced by acceleration. - Geometry of the track (cycloidal valley):
  The valley floor is one arch of a cycloid, parameterized by
  x(θ) = R(θ − sin θ), y(θ) = R(1 − cos θ), where y is measured downward and θ ∈ [0, 2π].
  Notable points:
  - Left rim: θ = 0, y = 0.
  - Bottom: θ = π, y = 2R.
  - Right rim: θ = 2π, y = 0.

- Object:
  A cube of initial mass M and side length r. It is released from rest at θ = 0, “facing the slope,” and slides without rolling (pure translation), so its kinetic energy is K = (1/2) m v^2.

- Snow layer:
  A stationary, adherent snow layer of surface density σ (mass per unit area) uniformly covers the valley surface. The snow is at rest with the ground until contacted; upon contact it sticks to the cube without changing its shape or causing rotation. As the cube slides an arc length ds along the curve, it sweeps area ≈ r ds (since r ≪ R), thus accreting mass dM = σ r ds.

- Small parameters/assumptions (retain up to first order in r):
  - σ r R ≪ M (total accreted mass is much smaller than M).
  - r ≪ R (curvature across the contact face is negligible; swept area ≈ r ds).
  - No rolling; the cube translates without rotation.
  - The track is otherwise smooth (no dry friction); the only tangential external force is the tangential component of gravity.
  - First-order treatment: evaluate kinematics (v, y, ds) to zeroth order in accretion (i.e., along the cycloid with mass ≈ M) when they appear as factors multiplying dM.

- Goal:
  Determine the highest position the cube reaches at the other rim (near θ = 2π). Define y_f > 0 as the vertical downward shortfall of the turning point below the right rim (i.e., the rim is at y = 0, and the turning point is at y = y_f). Compute y_f to first order in σ r R / M and r / R.

### Step 1
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{x(\theta) = R(\theta - \sin\theta), \quad y(\theta) = R(1 - \cos\theta)}\]
\[\boxed{ds = \sqrt{(dx)^2 + (dy)^2}, \quad \frac{ds}{d\theta} = \sqrt{\left(\frac{dx}{d\theta}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{dy}{d\theta}\right)^2}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Zeroth-order energy (no accretion): } \;\; v_0^2(\theta) = 2 g\, y(\theta)}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
\frac{dx}{d\theta} &= R(1 - \cos\theta) = 2R \sin^2\!\frac{\theta}{2}, 
\quad
\frac{dy}{d\theta} = R \sin\theta = 2R \sin\!\frac{\theta}{2}\cos\!\frac{\theta}{2}
\label{eq:dxdy} \tag{1}
\\
\frac{ds}{d\theta}
&= R \sqrt{(1 - \cos\theta)^2 + \sin^2\theta}
= R \sqrt{2 - 2\cos\theta}
= 2R \sin\!\frac{\theta}{2} \quad (0 \le \theta \le 2\pi)
\label{eq:dsdtheta} \tag{2}
\\
\text{Zeroth order (no accretion): } \quad 
\tfrac{1}{2} M v_0^2(\theta) &= M g\, y(\theta)
\;\Rightarrow\;
v_0^2(\theta) = 2 g\, y(\theta) = 2 g R(1 - \cos\theta).
\label{eq:v0} \tag{3}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 2
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{dM = \sigma\, r\, ds}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Variable-mass momentum balance: } \; d(m v) = F_{\text{ext}}\, dt + u\, dM}\]
\[\boxed{u = 0 \; \text{(incoming snow stationary in inertial frame)}, \quad F_{\tan} = m g \sin\alpha}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Power identity for accretion from rest: } \; d\!\left(\tfrac{1}{2} m v^2\right) = F_{\tan}\, ds - \tfrac{1}{2} v^2\, dM}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{Let } m \text{ be the instantaneous mass of the cube-plus-snow. Since the snow is stationary in the inertial frame, } u=0.
\label{eq:prem} \tag{4a}
\\
&\text{Thus } d(m v) = F_{\text{ext}}\, dt \ \Rightarrow\ m\, dv + v\, dM = F_{\tan}\, dt.
\label{eq:varmom} \tag{4b}
\\
&\text{Multiply by } v: \quad m v\, dv + v^2\, dM = F_{\tan}\, v\, dt = F_{\tan}\, ds.
\label{eq:power} \tag{5}
\\
&\text{Note } d\!\left(\tfrac{1}{2} m v^2\right) = \tfrac{1}{2} v^2\, dM + m v\, dv.
\ \text{Subtract } \tfrac{1}{2} v^2\, dM \text{ to obtain}
\label{eq:kinid} \tag{6}
\\
&\qquad d\!\left(\tfrac{1}{2} m v^2\right) = F_{\tan}\, ds - \tfrac{1}{2} v^2\, dM.
\label{eq:dK} \tag{7}
\\
&\text{On a smooth curve, the tangential component of gravity is } F_{\tan} = m g \sin\alpha,\ 
\sin\alpha\, ds = dy \ (\text{y downward}), 
\text{ so } F_{\tan}\, ds = m g\, dy.
\label{eq:gravwork} \tag{8}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 3
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{dK = m g\, dy - \tfrac{1}{2} v^2\, dM}\]
\[\boxed{K_{\text{start}} = K_{\text{turn}} = 0 \quad \text{(released from rest and turns at rest)}}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
dK &= m g\, dy - \frac{1}{2} v^2\, dM
\quad \text{(by \eqref{eq:dK} and \eqref{eq:gravwork})}
\label{eq:dKrepeat} \tag{9}
\\
\text{Integrate from release (}y=0\text{) to turning point (}y=y_f\text{): } \quad
0 - 0 &= \int m g\, dy - \int \frac{1}{2} v^2\, dM.
\label{eq:energyint} \tag{10}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 4
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\int m\, dy = [m y]_{\text{start}}^{\text{turn}} - \int y\, dm \quad \text{(integration by parts)}}\]
\[\boxed{v^2 \approx v_0^2 = 2 g y \quad \text{(zeroth-order kinematics, first-order accuracy in accretion)}}\]
\[\boxed{m_f = M + \Delta M, \ \Delta M = \int dM \sim \mathcal{O}(\sigma r R) \ll M}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
0 &= g \int m\, dy - \int \frac{1}{2} v^2\, dM
= g\left([m y]_{0}^{f} - \int y\, dm\right) - \int \frac{1}{2} v^2\, dm
\label{eq:byparts} \tag{11}
\\
\text{At } y=0 \text{ initially, } [m y]_0^f &= m_f y_f
\ \Rightarrow\ 
g\, m_f y_f = g \int y\, dm + \int \frac{1}{2} v^2\, dm.
\label{eq:keybal} \tag{12}
\\
\text{To first order, } v^2 &\approx v_0^2 = 2 g y\ \Rightarrow\ 
\int \frac{1}{2} v^2\, dm \approx \int g y\, dm.
\label{eq:vapprox} \tag{13}
\\
\Rightarrow\ g\, m_f y_f &\approx 2 g \int y\, dm
\ \Longrightarrow\ 
y_f \approx \frac{2}{m_f} \int y\, dm.
\label{eq:yfgeneral} \tag{14}
\\
\text{Since } m_f &= M + \mathcal{O}(\sigma r R), \ \text{to first order set } m_f \approx M:
\quad y_f \approx \frac{2}{M} \int y\, dm, \quad dm = dM = \sigma r\, ds.
\label{eq:yffirst} \tag{15}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 5
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{dm = \sigma r\, ds, \quad y(\theta) = R(1 - \cos\theta), \quad \frac{ds}{d\theta} = 2R \sin\frac{\theta}{2}}\]
\[\boxed{\int_0^{2\pi} (1 - \cos\theta)\, \sin\frac{\theta}{2}\, d\theta = \frac{16}{3}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{First-order path approximation: integrate over } \theta \in [0, 2\pi]}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
\int y\, dm &= \sigma r \int y\, ds
= \sigma r \int_{0}^{2\pi} y(\theta)\, \frac{ds}{d\theta}\, d\theta
\label{eq:intydm1} \tag{16}
\\
&= \sigma r \int_{0}^{2\pi} \big[R(1 - \cos\theta)\big]\, \big[2R \sin\frac{\theta}{2}\big]\, d\theta
= 2 \sigma r R^2 \int_{0}^{2\pi} (1 - \cos\theta)\, \sin\frac{\theta}{2}\, d\theta
\label{eq:intydm2} \tag{17}
\\
1 - \cos\theta &= 2 \sin^2\frac{\theta}{2}
\ \Rightarrow\ 
\int_{0}^{2\pi} (1 - \cos\theta)\, \sin\frac{\theta}{2}\, d\theta
= 2 \int_{0}^{2\pi} \sin^3\frac{\theta}{2}\, d\theta
\label{eq:reduce} \tag{18}
\\
t &= \frac{\theta}{2} \Rightarrow d\theta = 2\, dt,\; t: 0 \to \pi
\ \Rightarrow\ 
2 \int_{0}^{2\pi} \sin^3\frac{\theta}{2}\, d\theta
= 2 \cdot \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin^3 t \cdot 2\, dt
= 4 \cdot \frac{4}{3} = \frac{16}{3}
\label{eq:intval} \tag{19}
\\
\therefore\quad \int y\, dm &= 2 \sigma r R^2 \cdot \frac{16}{3}
= \frac{32}{3}\, \sigma r R^2.
\label{eq:intfinal} \tag{20}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 6
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{y_f \approx \frac{2}{M} \int y\, dm}\]
\[\boxed{\Delta M = \int dM = \sigma r \int ds = \sigma r \!\int_{0}^{2\pi} \frac{ds}{d\theta}\, d\theta = 8 \sigma r R \ll M}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
y_f &\approx \frac{2}{M} \cdot \frac{32}{3}\, \sigma r R^2
= \frac{64}{3}\, \frac{\sigma R^2 r}{M}.
\label{eq:yfresult} \tag{21}
\\
\text{Consistency of first-order approximation: } \quad
\Delta M &= \sigma r \!\int_{0}^{2\pi} 2R \sin\frac{\theta}{2}\, d\theta
= 4 \sigma r R \big[1 - \cos(\pi)\big] = 8 \sigma r R \ll M,
\label{eq:massgain} \tag{22}
\end{align}
\]
so replacing m_f by M incurs only second-order corrections.

### Final Answer
\[
\begin{align}
\boxed{y_f \;=\; \frac{64}{3}\,\frac{\sigma R^2 r}{M} \;+\; \mathcal{O}\!\left(\frac{(\sigma r R)^2}{M^2},\, \frac{r^2}{R}\right)}
\end{align}
\]

# Refined Solution
### Problem Statement Explanation
We are given an isotropic, rotationally symmetric refractive index distribution n = n(r) in the plane, such that a light ray follows the polar trajectory r(θ) = a cos(q θ) in the region 0 < r < a. Here:
- r is the radial coordinate from the origin,
- θ is the polar angle,
- a > 0 is a fixed length scale,
- q > 0 is a dimensionless parameter.

We work in geometric optics (ray optics). Because multiplying n(r) by a constant factor does not alter ray shapes (it only rescales optical path length), the refractive index is determined only up to a multiplicative, dimensionless constant n0. The task is to find n(r) (for r < a) that admits the given ray trajectory. It is noted that such an n(r) will diverge as r → 0, which is physically unrealistic but mathematically permissible.

Assumptions:
- Isotropic medium, n = n(r) only (no angular dependence),
- Rays are parameterized by arc length s when convenient,
- Standard optical mechanics (Fermat’s principle and conservation laws due to symmetry) applies.

### Step 1
- Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[
\boxed{\delta \int n(\mathbf{x})\, ds = 0 \quad \text{(Fermat's principle)}}
\]
\[
\boxed{L(\lambda) = n(r)\,\sqrt{\left(\frac{dr}{d\lambda}\right)^2 + r^2 \left(\frac{d\theta}{d\lambda}\right)^2} \quad \text{(optical Lagrangian for arbitrary parameter } \lambda)}
\]
\[
\boxed{p_\theta = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \left(d\theta/d\lambda\right)} = \text{const} \quad \text{(Noether's theorem for rotational symmetry)}}
\]

- Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
p_\theta 
&= \frac{\partial}{\partial \left(d\theta/d\lambda\right)}\left[n(r)\sqrt{\left(\frac{dr}{d\lambda}\right)^2 + r^2 \left(\frac{d\theta}{d\lambda}\right)^2}\right]
= n(r)\,\frac{r^2 \,\dfrac{d\theta}{d\lambda}}{\sqrt{\left(\dfrac{dr}{d\lambda}\right)^2 + r^2 \left(\dfrac{d\theta}{d\lambda}\right)^2}}
\label{eq:p-theta-gen} \tag{1} \\
&\text{Choose arc-length parameter } s \text{ so that } \left(\frac{dr}{ds}\right)^2 + \left(r\frac{d\theta}{ds}\right)^2 = 1
\label{eq:unit-speed} \tag{2} \\
&\text{Let } \alpha \text{ be the angle between the ray direction and outward radial direction, then }
\frac{dr}{ds} = \cos\alpha,\quad r\frac{d\theta}{ds} = \sin\alpha
\label{eq:geom} \tag{3} \\
\Rightarrow\quad 
p_\theta 
&= n(r)\,r^2 \frac{d\theta}{ds}
= n(r)\,r\,\sin\alpha 
\equiv J = \text{const} \quad \text{(Bouguer’s law).}
\label{eq:Bouguer} \tag{4}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 2
- Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[
\boxed{\frac{dr}{ds} = \cos\alpha,\quad r\frac{d\theta}{ds} = \sin\alpha}
\]
\[
\boxed{J = n(r)\,r\,\sin\alpha = \text{const}}
\]

- Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
\frac{d\theta}{dr} 
&= \frac{d\theta/ds}{dr/ds} 
= \frac{\sin\alpha}{r\cos\alpha}
= \frac{1}{r}\tan\alpha
\label{eq:dthdr-start} \tag{5} \\
\sin\alpha &= \frac{J}{n(r)\,r},
\qquad 
\cos\alpha = \sqrt{1 - \sin^2\alpha}
= \sqrt{1 - \frac{J^2}{n^2(r)\,r^2}}
\label{eq:trig} \tag{6} \\
\tan\alpha 
&= \frac{\sin\alpha}{\cos\alpha}
= \frac{\dfrac{J}{n(r)\,r}}{\sqrt{1 - \dfrac{J^2}{n^2(r)\,r^2}}}
= \frac{J}{\sqrt{n^2(r)\,r^2 - J^2}}
\label{eq:tanalpha} \tag{7} \\
\Rightarrow\quad
\frac{d\theta}{dr} 
&= \frac{1}{r}\,\tan\alpha
= \frac{J}{r\,\sqrt{n^2(r)\,r^2 - J^2}},
\qquad
\frac{dr}{d\theta} = \frac{r}{J}\,\sqrt{n^2(r)\,r^2 - J^2}.
\label{eq:drdth} \tag{8}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 3
- Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[
\boxed{\text{Squaring a first-order relation to eliminate branch signs preserves the functional } n(r)}
\]

- Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
\left(\frac{dr}{d\theta}\right)^2 
&= \frac{r^2}{J^2}\left(n^2(r)\,r^2 - J^2\right)
= \frac{n^2(r)\,r^4}{J^2} - r^2
\label{eq:square} \tag{9} \\
\Longrightarrow\quad
n^2(r) 
&= \frac{J^2}{r^4}\left[\left(\frac{dr}{d\theta}\right)^2 + r^2\right].
\label{eq:n2-master} \tag{10}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 4
- Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[
\boxed{r(\theta) = a\cos(q\theta)}
\]
\[
\boxed{\sin^2(q\theta) = 1 - \cos^2(q\theta)}
\]

- Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
\frac{dr}{d\theta} 
&= -a q \sin(q\theta)
\;\Rightarrow\;
\left(\frac{dr}{d\theta}\right)^2 
= a^2 q^2 \sin^2(q\theta)
\label{eq:drdth-trajectory} \tag{11} \\
\sin^2(q\theta) 
&= 1 - \cos^2(q\theta)
= 1 - \left(\frac{r}{a}\right)^2
\label{eq:sin2} \tag{12} \\
\Rightarrow\quad
\left(\frac{dr}{d\theta}\right)^2 
&= a^2 q^2 \left(1 - \frac{r^2}{a^2}\right)
= a^2 q^2 - q^2 r^2.
\label{eq:drdth2} \tag{13}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 5
- Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[
\boxed{n(r)\to \lambda\,n(r) \;\Rightarrow\; \text{ray shapes unchanged (overall scale gauge)}}
\]
\[
\boxed{J = n(r)\,r\,\sin\alpha \;\Rightarrow\; J \to \lambda\,J \text{ under } n \to \lambda n}
\]

- Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
\text{Insert \eqref{eq:drdth2} into \eqref{eq:n2-master}:}\quad
n^2(r) 
&= \frac{J^2}{r^4}\left[a^2 q^2 - q^2 r^2 + r^2\right]
= \frac{J^2}{r^4}\left[a^2 q^2 + (1 - q^2)\,r^2\right]
\label{eq:n2-J} \tag{14} \\
\text{Fix overall scale by setting } |J| &= n_0\, a,\quad n_0>0 \text{ (dimensionless)}
\label{eq:n0-def} \tag{15} \\
\Rightarrow\quad
n^2(r) 
&= \frac{n_0^2 a^2}{r^4}\left[a^2 q^2 + (1 - q^2)\,r^2\right]
= n_0^2 a^2\left(\frac{a^{2} q^{2}}{r^{4}} - \frac{q^{2}-1}{r^{2}}\right)
\label{eq:n2-final} \tag{16} \\
\therefore\quad
n(r) 
&= n_{0}\, a \,\sqrt{\frac{a^{2} q^{2}}{r^{4}} - \frac{q^{2} - 1}{r^{2}}}, 
\qquad 0<r<a.
\label{eq:n-final} \tag{17}
\end{align}
\]
The radicand is positive for 0<r≤a since a^2 q^2 - (q^2 - 1) r^2 = q^2(a^2 - r^2) + r^2 > 0. As r→0, n(r) ~ (n_0 a^2 q)/r^2, consistent with the stated central divergence. At r = a, n(a) = n_0.

### Final Answer
\[
\begin{align}
n(r) = n_{0}\, a \,\sqrt{\frac{a^{2} q^{2}}{r^{4}} - \frac{q^{2} - 1}{r^{2}}}, \quad 0<r<a.
\end{align}
\]

questions:
Calculate the wave speed of longitudinal waves in a one-dimensional gas. Consider a section of the gas column with cross-sectional area $S$, assume its displacement along the $x$ direction is $\xi = \xi(x)$, the gas pressure distribution is $p = p(x)$, and the density of the gas when uncompressed is $\rho_{0}$. Consider the case of small amplitude and long wavelength, i.e. $\xi \ll x, \frac{\partial \xi}{\partial x}\ll 1, (p-p_0)\ll p_0, (\rho-\rho_0)\ll\rho_0$. Calculate the wave speed of longitudinal waves in a van der Waals gas. The state equation of one mole of the gas is given as:

$$
\left( p + \frac{a}{V^{2}} \right)(V - b) = RT\ 
$$

The molar heat capacity at constant volume is $c_{v}$, and the molar mass of the gas is $\mu$. Solve for the wave speed under adiabatic conditions, expressed in terms of $p, \rho, a, b,\mu, \gamma = \frac{c_{v} + R}{c_{v}}$.  
Hint: You can use the formulas:

$$dU = c_{v}dT + \left( \frac{\partial U}{\partial V} \right)_{T}dV$$

and

$$\left( \frac{\partial U}{\partial V} \right)_{T} = T\left( \frac{\partial p}{\partial T} \right)_{V} - p$$

to calculate the adiabatic equation.
solutions:
Consider the air column from $x \rightarrow x + dx$. From the dynamics equation, we obtain:

$$
\rho_{0}Sdx\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial t^{2}} = - \frac{dp}{dS}(1)
$$

After simplification, we get

$$
\rho_{0}\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial t^{2}} = - \frac{\partial p}{\partial x}(2)
$$

Consider the air column originally located at $x\rightarrow x+\mathrm d x$, now located at $x+\xi\rightarrow x+dx+\xi +d\xi$. By mass conservation:

$$
\rho(d\xi + dx) = \rho_{0}dx(3)
$$

Hence, we get

$$
\rho = \rho_{0}\left( 1 - \frac{\partial\xi}{\partial x} \right)(4)
$$

Using

$$
\frac{\partial p}{\partial x} = \left( \frac{\partial p}{\partial\rho} \right)_{c} \cdot \frac{\partial\rho}{\partial x}(5)
$$

we obtain

$$
\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial t^{2}} = \left( \frac{\partial p}{\partial\rho} \right)_{c}\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial x^{2}}(6)
$$

The wave speed is

$$
v = \sqrt{\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}}
$$

Using the formula from the hint, we obtain

$$
\left( \frac{\partial U}{\partial V} \right)_{T} = T\left( \frac{\partial p}{\partial T} \right)_{V} - p = \frac{a}{V^{2}}(7)
$$

First Law of Thermodynamics

$$
dQ = dU + dW(8)
$$

$$
0 = c_{v}dT + \frac{a}{V^{2}}dV + pdV = c_{v}dT + \frac{RT}{V - b}dV(9)
$$

Integrating and substituting into the state equation, we obtain

$$
\left( p + \frac{a}{V^{2}} \right)(V - b)^{\frac{c_{v} + R}{C_{v}}} = C(10)
$$

Using

$$
V = \frac{\mu}{\rho}(11)
$$

Taking the logarithm of equation (10) and then differentiating, we obtain:

$$
v = \sqrt{\left. \left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial\rho} \right. \right)_{s}} = \sqrt{\frac{\gamma\mu}{\mu\rho - b\rho^{2}}\left( p + \frac{a}{\mu^{2}}\rho^{2} \right) - \frac{2a\rho}{\mu^{2}}}(12)
$$

# Refined Solution
### Problem Statement Explanation
We consider small-amplitude, long-wavelength longitudinal waves in a one-dimensional gas column of constant cross-sectional area S. The gas is described by the displacement field ξ(x,t) along the x direction, pressure p(x,t), and density ρ(x,t). The unperturbed (uncompressed) density is ρ0, and smallness assumptions hold: ξ ≪ x, |∂ξ/∂x| ≪ 1, |p − p0| ≪ p0, |ρ − ρ0| ≪ ρ0. Dissipation and heat conduction are neglected, so the wave process is adiabatic and, for small perturbations, isentropic.

The gas obeys the van der Waals equation of state for one mole:
(p + a/V^2)(V − b) = RT,
where V is the molar volume, a and b are van der Waals constants, R is the universal gas constant, and T is temperature. The molar heat capacity at constant volume is cv (assumed constant), the molar mass is μ, and we define γ = (cv + R)/cv. The density ρ is related to the molar volume by V = μ/ρ.

We are to derive the wave speed v of longitudinal (sound) waves under adiabatic (isentropic) conditions, and express it in terms of p, ρ, a, b, μ, and γ.

### Step 1
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\text{Newton's second law: } F_{\text{net}} = m\,a}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Pressure gradient force on a slice: } F_{\text{net}} = -S\,\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\,dx}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Small-amplitude linearization: mass } m \approx \rho_{0}S\,dx}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{Consider the slice } [x,x+dx].\ \text{Its mass is } m \approx \rho_{0}S\,dx.\ \text{The net force from pressure is} \nonumber\\
&F_{\text{net}} = S\,p(x,t) - S\,p(x+dx,t) \approx -S\,\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\,dx. \label{eq:force}\tag{1}\\
&\text{Newton's second law with displacement } \xi(x,t):\ a = \frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial t^{2}}. \nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow \rho_{0}S\,dx\,\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial t^{2}} = -S\,\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}\,dx. \nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow \rho_{0}\,\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial t^{2}} = -\frac{\partial p}{\partial x}. \label{eq:motion}\tag{2}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 2
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\text{Mass conservation in 1D: } \rho(x,t)\,[1+\partial\xi/\partial x] = \rho_{0}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Small strain: } |\partial\xi/\partial x|\ll 1}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{A material line element initially of length } dx \text{ deforms to } dx + \partial\xi/\partial x\,dx. \nonumber\\
&\text{Mass conservation gives } \rho\,S\left(dx+\frac{\partial\xi}{\partial x}\,dx\right) = \rho_{0}S\,dx. \nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow \rho\left(1+\frac{\partial\xi}{\partial x}\right)=\rho_{0}. \label{eq:mass}\tag{3}\\
&\text{To first order, } \rho = \rho_{0}\left(1 - \frac{\partial\xi}{\partial x}\right),\ \ \Rightarrow\ \ \frac{\partial\rho}{\partial x} = -\rho_{0}\,\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial x^{2}}. \label{eq:rho_xi}\tag{4}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 3
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\text{Isentropic (adiabatic, reversible) sound speed: } v^{2} = \left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{s}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Chain rule: } \frac{\partial p}{\partial x} = \left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{s}\,\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial x}}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{Using \eqref{eq:rho_xi} in the chain rule,} \quad \frac{\partial p}{\partial x} = \left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{s}\left(-\rho_{0}\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial x^{2}}\right). \label{eq:chain}\tag{5}\\
&\text{Insert \eqref{eq:chain} into the motion equation \eqref{eq:motion}:} \nonumber\\
&\rho_{0}\,\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial t^{2}} = -\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{s}\left(-\rho_{0}\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial x^{2}}\right). \nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow \frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial t^{2}} = \left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{s}\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial x^{2}} \equiv v^{2}\,\frac{\partial^{2}\xi}{\partial x^{2}}. \label{eq:wave}\tag{6}
\end{align}
\]
Thus the sound speed is determined by the isentropic derivative v^{2} = (∂p/∂ρ)_{s}.

### Step 4
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\text{van der Waals EOS (1 mole): } \left(p+\frac{a}{V^{2}}\right)(V-b)=RT}\]
\[\boxed{dU = c_{v}\,dT + \left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial V}\right)_{T} dV}\]
\[\boxed{\left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial V}\right)_{T} = T\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial T}\right)_{V} - p}\]
\[\boxed{\text{First law: } dQ = dU + p\,dV}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Adiabatic condition: } dQ = 0}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Assumption: } c_{v} \text{ is constant; } \gamma=\frac{c_{v}+R}{c_{v}}}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{From the vdW EOS: } p(T,V)=\frac{RT}{V-b}-\frac{a}{V^{2}} \ \Rightarrow\ \left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial T}\right)_{V}=\frac{R}{V-b}. \nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow \left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial V}\right)_{T}=T\frac{R}{V-b}-p=\frac{a}{V^{2}}. \label{eq:U_V}\tag{7}\\
&\text{Adiabaticity } (dQ=0):\ 0=dU+p\,dV=c_{v}\,dT+\left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial V}\right)_{T}dV+p\,dV \nonumber\\
&\qquad\qquad\qquad\quad = c_{v}\,dT+\left(\frac{a}{V^{2}}+p\right)dV = c_{v}\,dT+\frac{RT}{V-b}\,dV. \label{eq:adiabatic_diff}\tag{8}\\
&\text{Rearrange and integrate (with constant } c_{v}\text{): } \frac{dT}{T}=-\frac{R}{c_{v}}\frac{dV}{V-b}. \nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow \ln T = -\frac{R}{c_{v}}\ln(V-b)+\text{const} \ \Rightarrow\ T(V-b)^{R/c_{v}}=\text{const}. \label{eq:T_V}\tag{9}\\
&\text{Using } (p+a/V^{2})(V-b)=RT,\ \text{eliminate } T \text{ to get} \nonumber\\
&\boxed{\ (p+\frac{a}{V^{2}})(V-b)^{\gamma}=\text{const}\ },\quad \gamma=1+\frac{R}{c_{v}}=\frac{c_{v}+R}{c_{v}}. \label{eq:adiabatic_vdw}\tag{10}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 5
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\text{Isentropic sound speed: } v^{2}=\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{s}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Implicit differentiation at constant } s:\ G(p,V)=(p+\frac{a}{V^{2}})(V-b)^{\gamma}=\text{const} \Rightarrow \frac{\partial G}{\partial p}dp+\frac{\partial G}{\partial V}dV=0}\]
\[\boxed{V=\frac{\mu}{\rho},\quad \frac{dV}{d\rho}=-\frac{\mu}{\rho^{2}},\quad \left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{s}=\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial V}\right)_{s}\frac{dV}{d\rho}}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{Let } G(p,V)=(p+\frac{a}{V^{2}})(V-b)^{\gamma}.\ \text{At constant } s:\ dG=0. \nonumber\\
&\frac{\partial G}{\partial p}=(V-b)^{\gamma},\quad \frac{\partial G}{\partial V}=\left(-\frac{2a}{V^{3}}\right)(V-b)^{\gamma}+\left(p+\frac{a}{V^{2}}\right)\gamma (V-b)^{\gamma-1}. \nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow (V-b)^{\gamma}\,dp+\Big[-\frac{2a}{V^{3}}(V-b)^{\gamma}+\left(p+\frac{a}{V^{2}}\right)\gamma (V-b)^{\gamma-1}\Big]\,dV=0. \nonumber\\
&\text{Divide by } (V-b)^{\gamma-1}:\ (V-b)\,dp+\left[-\frac{2a}{V^{3}}(V-b)+\gamma\left(p+\frac{a}{V^{2}}\right)\right]\,dV=0. \nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow \left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial V}\right)_{s}=-\frac{-\frac{2a}{V^{3}}(V-b)+\gamma\left(p+\frac{a}{V^{2}}\right)}{V-b} \nonumber\\
&\qquad\qquad\qquad\quad = -\frac{\gamma\left(p+\frac{a}{V^{2}}\right)}{V-b}+\frac{2a}{V^{3}}. \label{eq:dpdV_s}\tag{11}\\
&\text{Convert to } \left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{s}:\ \left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{s}=\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial V}\right)_{s}\left(-\frac{\mu}{\rho^{2}}\right). \nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow v^{2}=\left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{s}=-\frac{\mu}{\rho^{2}}\left[-\frac{\gamma\left(p+\frac{a}{V^{2}}\right)}{V-b}+\frac{2a}{V^{3}}\right]. \label{eq:v2_beforeSub}\tag{12}\\
&\text{Substitute } V=\frac{\mu}{\rho}: \ \frac{1}{V-b}=\frac{\rho}{\mu-b\rho},\ \ \frac{1}{V^{2}}=\frac{\rho^{2}}{\mu^{2}},\ \ \frac{1}{V^{3}}=\frac{\rho^{3}}{\mu^{3}}. \nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow v^{2}=\frac{\mu}{\rho^{2}}\left[\gamma\left(p+\frac{a\rho^{2}}{\mu^{2}}\right)\frac{\rho}{\mu-b\rho}-\frac{2a\rho^{3}}{\mu^{3}}\right] \nonumber\\
&\qquad\quad = \frac{\gamma\mu}{\mu\rho - b\rho^{2}}\left(p+\frac{a\rho^{2}}{\mu^{2}}\right)-\frac{2a\rho}{\mu^{2}}. \label{eq:v2_final}\tag{13}
\end{align}
\]
Therefore, the adiabatic (isentropic) sound speed satisfies v^{2} given by \eqref{eq:v2_final}, and v is its square root.

### Final Answer
\[
\begin{align}
v^{2} &= \left(\frac{\partial p}{\partial \rho}\right)_{s} = \frac{\gamma\mu}{\mu\rho - b\rho^{2}}\left(p+\frac{a\rho^{2}}{\mu^{2}}\right)-\frac{2a\rho}{\mu^{2}},\\
v &= \sqrt{\,\frac{\gamma\mu}{\mu\rho - b\rho^{2}}\left(p+\frac{a\rho^{2}}{\mu^{2}}\right)-\frac{2a\rho}{\mu^{2}}\,}.
\end{align}
\]

questions:
The curling can be approximated as a solid homogeneous cylinder with mass $m$, bottom surface radius $r$, and height $h$. Only the outer edge of the bottom is in contact with the ice surface, which has a friction coefficient $\mu$. The support force of the ice surface on the curling stone is $N=\int_{0}^{2\pi}n(\theta)\mathrm{d}\theta$,
where $n(\theta)$ is the distribution of the support force according to the polar coordinate $\theta$. When the curling is stationary on the horizontal ice surface, $n(\theta)=mg/2\pi$. Assume that the deformation of the outer edge of the curling is very small, and the elastic force satisfies Hooke's law. Therefore, it can be proven that the support force distribution has the form $n(\theta)=n_0+n_1\cos(\theta-\theta_0)$ (where $n_0$, $n_1$, and $\theta_0$ are unknown quantities). If the curling has a velocity $v$ in the positive direction along the x-axis, and also has an angular velocity $\omega$ in the clockwise direction (viewed from above), the curling will generate a lateral acceleration $a$ in the y-direction. It is through this that the athlete can achieve the curling's turn. Find the expression for $a_y$ in the limit case where $v\gg\omega r$.
solutions:
The deformation at a particular point $\pmb{d}$ is a linear function of its projection distance $\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\rho}}_{x}$ in the direction of maximum deformation:  

$$
d = d_{0} + x \tan\alpha
$$  

Assuming the direction of maximum deformation is $\theta_{0}$, we have:  

$$
x = r \cos{\left(\theta - \theta_{0}\right)}
$$  

According to Hooke's law:  

$$
n = k d = k d_{0} + k r \tan\alpha \cos\left(\theta - \theta_{0}\right) = n_{0} + n_{1} \cos\left(\theta - \theta_{0}\right)
$$  

The curling stone is in vertical force equilibrium, so:  

$$
N = \int_{0}^{2\pi} n\big(\theta\big)d\theta = m g
$$  

Solving, we obtain $n_{0} = m g / 2\pi$.  

The friction force acting on the curling stone is proportional to the normal pressure:  

$$
f(\theta) = \mu n(\theta)
$$  

Its direction is along the negative $\mathbf{x}$ axis.  

During the motion of the curling stone, the overall torque is balanced:  

$$
M_{x} = \int_{0}^{2\pi}\boldsymbol{n}(\theta) r \sin\theta d\theta + \frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{2\pi} f_{y}\left(\theta\right) h d\theta = 0
$$  

$$
M_{y} = -\int_{0}^{2\pi} \eta \left(\theta\right) r \cos\theta d\theta - \frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{2\pi} f_{x}\left(\theta\right) h d\theta = 0
$$  

When $\nu \gg \omega r$, the components of the friction force retain only the first-order approximations:  

$$
f_{x} = -\frac{\nu + \omega r \sin\theta}{\sqrt{\left(\nu + \omega r \sin\theta\right)^{2} + \omega^{2} r^{2} \cos^{2}\theta}} \mu n(\theta) \approx -\mu n(\theta)
$$  

$$
f_{y} = \frac{\omega r \cos{\theta}}{\sqrt{\left(\nu + \omega r \sin{\theta}\right)^{2} + \omega^{2} r^{2} \cos^{2}{\theta}}} \mu n(\theta) \approx \frac{\omega r \cos{\theta}}{\nu} \mu n(\theta)
$$  

For convenience in solving, let $n\left(\theta\right) = n_{0} + a \cos\theta + b \sin\theta$. Substituting into equations (6) and (7) and solving simultaneously, we obtain:  

$$
n\left(\theta\right) = \frac{m g}{2\pi} \left(1 + \frac{\mu h}{r} \cos\theta - \frac{\mu^{2} h^{2} \omega}{2 \nu r} \sin\theta\right)
$$  

The final transverse acceleration is:  

$$
a_{y} = \frac{1}{m} \int_{0}^{2\pi} f_{y} d\theta = \frac{\mu^{2} \omega h g}{2 \nu}
$$

# Refined Solution
### Problem Statement Explanation
We model the curling stone as a solid homogeneous cylinder of mass m, radius r (for the narrow outer edge that contacts the ice), and height h. The stone rests on a horizontal ice surface and only its outer bottom edge contacts the ice. The ice exerts:
- A distributed normal (support) force around the contact ring: n(θ), such that the total normal force is N = ∫₀^{2π} n(θ) dθ.
- A Coulomb friction force with coefficient μ, acting opposite the local slip at each contact point.

In static equilibrium (no motion), symmetry implies n(θ) = mg/(2π). For small elastic deformation of the edge and linear elasticity (Hooke’s law), the normal-load distribution around the contact ring (per unit angle) can be taken to first harmonic form:
n(θ) = n0 + n1 cos(θ − θ0), where n0, n1, θ0 are to be determined by force and torque balances during motion.

The stone’s center of mass translates with speed v along +x, and the stone spins clockwise (viewed from above) with angular speed ω. Using a right-handed coordinate system with z upward, a clockwise spin corresponds to angular velocity vector Ω = −ω k. We are to determine the lateral acceleration a_y (in the y-direction) caused by the frictional interaction, in the limit v ≫ ω r.

Assumptions:
- Narrow ring contact; n(θ) is the normal force per unit angle, and the local friction magnitude is μ n(θ).
- Linear elasticity (Hooke’s law) with small deformation, justifying a single-harmonic n(θ).
- The stone remains upright (no rotation about x or y), so net torques about x and y vanish (quasi-static tilt balance).
- Net torque about z (spin) is not constrained to zero.
- We expand to first order in ε = (ω r)/v ≪ 1 and neglect O(ε²) terms.

### Step 1
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{N=\int_{0}^{2\pi} n(\theta)\,\mathrm{d}\theta}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Hooke’s law: }\sigma = E\,\varepsilon \quad \Rightarrow\ \text{(for small deformations) pressure varies linearly with indentation}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{First-harmonic load distribution:}\quad n(\theta)=n_0+n_1\cos(\theta-\theta_0)}\]

Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{In the static case, symmetry gives } n(\theta)=\frac{mg}{2\pi}.\ \text{Under small deformation with linear elasticity, the leading angular} \nonumber\\
&\text{dependence is a single harmonic: }n(\theta)=n_0+n_1\cos(\theta-\theta_0).\ \text{The total normal force must balance weight:}\nonumber\\
N&=\int_0^{2\pi} n(\theta)\,\mathrm{d}\theta = mg \ \Rightarrow\ 2\pi n_0 = mg \ \Rightarrow\ n_0=\frac{mg}{2\pi}.
\label{eq:n0} \tag{1}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 2
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{\text{Rigid-body kinematics:}\quad \mathbf{v}_P=\mathbf{v}_{\mathrm{CM}}+\boldsymbol{\Omega}\times\boldsymbol{\rho}}\]
\[\boxed{\boldsymbol{\Omega}=-\omega\,\mathbf{k}\quad \text{(clockwise viewed from above)}}\]

Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{Let the CM be at the cylinder’s midpoint; the contact ring lies a distance }h/2\text{ below the CM.}\nonumber\\
&\text{A contact point at polar angle }\theta\text{ has } \boldsymbol{\rho} = r\cos\theta\,\mathbf{i}+r\sin\theta\,\mathbf{j}-\frac{h}{2}\,\mathbf{k}.\nonumber\\
&\text{With } \mathbf{v}_{\mathrm{CM}}=v\,\mathbf{i} \text{ and } \boldsymbol{\Omega}=-\omega\mathbf{k},\ \text{the slip velocity relative to the ice is}\nonumber\\
\mathbf{v}_{\text{rel}}(\theta) &= \mathbf{v}_{\mathrm{CM}}+\boldsymbol{\Omega}\times\boldsymbol{\rho}
= v\,\mathbf{i} + (-\omega\mathbf{k})\times\left(r\cos\theta\,\mathbf{i}+r\sin\theta\,\mathbf{j}-\frac{h}{2}\mathbf{k}\right)\nonumber\\
&= v\,\mathbf{i} + \left(-\omega r\cos\theta\,\mathbf{j} + \omega r\sin\theta\,\mathbf{i}\right) \nonumber\\
&= \big(v+\omega r\sin\theta\big)\,\mathbf{i} - \omega r\cos\theta\,\mathbf{j}.
\label{eq:vrel} \tag{2}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 3
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{\text{Coulomb friction (local):}\quad \mathrm{d}\mathbf{F}_f(\theta)=-\mu\,n(\theta)\,\frac{\mathbf{v}_{\text{rel}}(\theta)}{\|\mathbf{v}_{\text{rel}}(\theta)\|}\,\mathrm{d}\theta}\]
\[\boxed{\|\mathbf{v}_{\text{rel}}(\theta)\|=\sqrt{\big(v+\omega r\sin\theta\big)^2+(\omega r\cos\theta)^2}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{First-order in }\varepsilon=\omega r/v\ll 1:\quad \|\mathbf{v}_{\text{rel}}\|\approx v+\omega r\sin\theta}\]

Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{From \eqref{eq:vrel}, the friction components on the stone are}\nonumber\\
f_x(\theta) &= -\mu\,n(\theta)\,\frac{v+\omega r\sin\theta}{\sqrt{\big(v+\omega r\sin\theta\big)^2+(\omega r\cos\theta)^2}},\quad
f_y(\theta) = \mu\,n(\theta)\,\frac{\omega r\cos\theta}{\|\mathbf{v}_{\text{rel}}\|}.
\label{eq:fxfy_exact} \tag{3}
\end{align}
\]
For v ≫ ω r, keeping only O(ε) terms,
\[
\begin{align}
\|\mathbf{v}_{\text{rel}}\| &\approx v+\omega r\sin\theta,\nonumber\\
\Rightarrow\quad f_x(\theta) &\approx -\mu\,n(\theta),\qquad
f_y(\theta) \approx \mu\,n(\theta)\,\frac{\omega r\cos\theta}{v}.
\label{eq:fxfy_approx} \tag{4}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 4
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{\sum F_z=0\ \Rightarrow\ \int_0^{2\pi} n(\theta)\,\mathrm{d}\theta=mg}\]
\[\boxed{\sum \tau_x=I_x \alpha_x=0,\ \ \sum \tau_y=I_y \alpha_y=0\ \ \text{(upright motion: no pitch/roll)}}\]
\[\boxed{\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{\tau}=\boldsymbol{\rho}\times \mathrm{d}\mathbf{F}}\]

Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{At angle }\theta,\ \boldsymbol{\rho}=r\cos\theta\,\mathbf{i}+r\sin\theta\,\mathbf{j}-\frac{h}{2}\,\mathbf{k}.\ \ 
\mathrm{d}\mathbf{F}_n = n(\theta)\,\mathbf{k}\,\mathrm{d}\theta,\ \ 
\mathrm{d}\mathbf{F}_f = f_x(\theta)\,\mathbf{i}\,\mathrm{d}\theta+f_y(\theta)\,\mathbf{j}\,\mathrm{d}\theta.\nonumber\\
&\text{Normal torque: } \mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{\tau}_n=\boldsymbol{\rho}\times \mathrm{d}\mathbf{F}_n
= n(\theta)\,r\big(\sin\theta\,\mathbf{i}-\cos\theta\,\mathbf{j}\big)\,\mathrm{d}\theta.\nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow\ \ \tau_{x}^{(n)}=\int_0^{2\pi} n(\theta)\,r\sin\theta\,\mathrm{d}\theta,\quad
\tau_{y}^{(n)}=-\int_0^{2\pi} n(\theta)\,r\cos\theta\,\mathrm{d}\theta.\nonumber\\
&\text{Friction torque: } \mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{\tau}_f=\boldsymbol{\rho}\times \mathrm{d}\mathbf{F}_f
=\left(\frac{h}{2}f_y\right)\mathbf{i}\,\mathrm{d}\theta-\left(\frac{h}{2}f_x\right)\mathbf{j}\,\mathrm{d}\theta
+\big(r\cos\theta\,f_y-r\sin\theta\,f_x\big)\mathbf{k}\,\mathrm{d}\theta.\nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow\ \ \tau_{x}^{(f)}=\int_0^{2\pi}\frac{h}{2}f_y(\theta)\,\mathrm{d}\theta,\quad
\tau_{y}^{(f)}=-\int_0^{2\pi}\frac{h}{2}f_x(\theta)\,\mathrm{d}\theta.\nonumber\\
&\text{Write } n(\theta)=n_0+A\cos\theta+B\sin\theta,\ \text{so that }\ \int n\sin\theta\,\mathrm{d}\theta=B\pi,\ \int n\cos\theta\,\mathrm{d}\theta=A\pi,\ \int n\,\mathrm{d}\theta=mg.\nonumber\\
&\text{Using \eqref{eq:fxfy_approx}:}\ \ \tau_x\!: 0=\tau_x^{(n)}+\tau_x^{(f)}= r(B\pi) + \frac{h}{2}\left(\mu\frac{\omega r}{v}\right)(A\pi).\nonumber\\
&\tau_y\!: 0=\tau_y^{(n)}+\tau_y^{(f)}= -r(A\pi) - \frac{h}{2}\int_0^{2\pi} f_x\,\mathrm{d}\theta
= -r(A\pi) - \frac{h}{2}\int_0^{2\pi}(-\mu n)\,\mathrm{d}\theta
= -r(A\pi) + \frac{h}{2}\mu\,mg.\nonumber\\
&\Rightarrow\ \ A = \frac{\mu h\,mg}{2\pi r},\qquad
B = -\frac{h\mu\omega}{2v}\,A = -\frac{\mu^2 h^2 \omega\,mg}{4\pi v r}.
\label{eq:A_B} \tag{5}
\end{align}
\]
With n0 from \eqref{eq:n0}, the load distribution is
\[
\begin{align}
n(\theta)
&= \frac{mg}{2\pi} + A\cos\theta + B\sin\theta \nonumber\\
&= \frac{mg}{2\pi}\left[1 + \frac{\mu h}{r}\cos\theta - \frac{\mu^2 h^2 \omega}{2 v r}\,\sin\theta\right],
\label{eq:n_theta} \tag{6}
\end{align}
\]
which is equivalent to n(θ)=n0+n1 cos(θ−θ0) to first order in ω r/v.

### Step 5
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions:
\[\boxed{F_y=\int_0^{2\pi} f_y(\theta)\,\mathrm{d}\theta}\]
\[\boxed{f_y(\theta)\approx \mu\,n(\theta)\,\frac{\omega r\cos\theta}{v}\quad \text{(first order in }\varepsilon)}\]
\[\boxed{a_y=\frac{F_y}{m}\ \ \text{(Newton’s second law)}}\]

Derivation:
\[
\begin{align}
F_y &\approx \int_0^{2\pi} \mu\,n(\theta)\,\frac{\omega r\cos\theta}{v}\,\mathrm{d}\theta
= \mu\,\frac{\omega r}{v}\,\int_0^{2\pi} n(\theta)\cos\theta\,\mathrm{d}\theta
= \mu\,\frac{\omega r}{v}\,(A\pi). \nonumber\\
&\text{Using }A=\frac{\mu h\,mg}{2\pi r}\ \text{ from \eqref{eq:A_B}},\quad
F_y = \mu\,\frac{\omega r}{v}\,\pi\left(\frac{\mu h\,mg}{2\pi r}\right)
= \frac{\mu^2\,\omega\,h\,mg}{2v}. \nonumber\\
\Rightarrow\quad a_y &= \frac{F_y}{m} = \frac{\mu^2\,\omega\,h\,g}{2v}.
\label{eq:ay} \tag{7}
\end{align}
\]
For ω defined as clockwise (Ω = −ω k), the sign in \eqref{eq:ay} corresponds to a lateral acceleration along +y.

### Final Answer
\[
\begin{align}
a_y = \frac{\mu^2\,\omega\,h\,g}{2\,v}\qquad\text{(valid for }v\gg \omega r,\ \text{clockwise spin)}
\end{align}
\]

questions: The forty-second batch of Trisolarian immigrants arrived on Earth aboard a spaceship propelled by photons. The spaceship has a rest mass of $M$, and it uses the method of annihilating matter and antimatter to produce photons, which are then emitted directly backward to provide thrust. In the reference frame of the spaceship, the frequency of the photons emitted backward is $ u _{0}$. For simplicity, we assume that the \"windward side\" of the Trisolarian spaceship is a flat surface with an area $S$. During flight, dust floating in the universe may collide with it. We assume that the cosmic dust is composed of particles with rest mass $m$. For an observer on Earth: the spaceship moves at a constant speed of $v _1$, the particles in the cosmic dust have a speed of $v_2$ and move in the same direction as the spaceship, and the particles in the dust are uniformly distributed with a density of $n$. If, according to the Trisolarian beings on the spaceship, the cosmic dust undergoes a \"perfectly elastic collision\" upon impact with the spaceship, what is the number $N^{'}$ of photons that need to be emitted backward per unit time in the reference frame of the spaceship to maintain its constant speed? Given are Planck's constant $h$, the speed of light in vacuum $c$, and relativistic effects need to be considered.
solutions: There are two reference frames; let's set up the agreements first. The reference frame of the Earth observer is called the $\Sigma$ frame, and the reference frame of the spaceship is called the $\Sigma$ frame.  We agree that: $$\beta_{1}=\frac{v_{1}}{c},\gamma_{1}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{1}^{2}}},\beta_{2}=\frac{v_{2}}{c},\gamma_{2}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{2}^{2}}},\beta_{21}=\frac{v_{21}}{c},\gamma_{21}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{21}^{2}}}$$ $$\beta_{2}^{'}=\frac{v_{2}^{'}}{c},\gamma_{2}^{'}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{2}^{'2}}},\beta_{21}^{'}=\frac{v_{21}^{'}}{c},\gamma_{21}^{'}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta_{21}^{'2}}}$$    The resistance of the spaceship is equal to the impulse given to the spaceship by cosmic dust particles per unit time. # Refined Solution
### Problem Statement Explanation
We analyze a photon-rocket spaceship traveling rectilinearly. It has rest mass M and propels itself by emitting photons produced via matter–antimatter annihilation. In the spaceship’s rest frame S′, photons are emitted directly backward (opposite the direction of motion) with frequency u0. The “windward” side (facing the incoming dust) is idealized as a flat plate of area S perpendicular to the motion.

The interstellar dust is modeled as identical particles of rest mass m. In the Earth (lab) frame S:
- The spaceship moves at constant speed v1 along the +x direction.
- The dust moves in the same +x direction with speed v2.
- The dust number density is uniform and equal to n.

For observers on the spaceship (frame S′), dust impacts the windward plate and undergoes a perfectly elastic collision with the plate. In the plate’s rest frame (S′), “perfectly elastic” means the dust particle’s kinetic energy is conserved and the normal component of its momentum reverses sign upon reflection from an immovable wall.

Goal: Find N′, the number of photons emitted backward per unit time (as measured in S′) required to maintain the spaceship’s constant speed, accounting for relativistic effects. Given: Planck’s constant h and the speed of light c.

Assumptions and conventions:
- v1 > v2 so dust approaches and collides with the windward plate in S′.
- The area S is perpendicular to the boost direction; areas perpendicular to the boost are invariant, so S is the same in S and S′.
- Define βi = vi/c and γi = 1/√(1 − βi^2) for i = 1, 2. The dust speed and Lorentz factor in S′ are v′ and γ′. The dust density in S′ is n′.

### Step 1
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{v'=\frac{v_2-v_1}{\,1-\dfrac{v_1 v_2}{c^2}\,}\quad\text{(relativistic velocity addition, colinear)}}\]
\[\boxed{\gamma'=\gamma_1\,\gamma_2\,\big(1-\beta_1\beta_2\big)\quad\text{(relative Lorentz factor, colinear)}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Areas perpendicular to the boost direction are invariant under Lorentz boosts}}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{Transform the dust velocity from S to the spaceship frame S′ (colinear case):}\nonumber\\
v'&=\frac{v_2-v_1}{1-\dfrac{v_1 v_2}{c^2}},\qquad \beta'=\frac{v'}{c}. \label{eq:vprime}\tag{1}\\
&\text{The corresponding Lorentz factor (identity for colinear velocities):}\nonumber\\
\gamma'&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta'^2}}
=\gamma_1\,\gamma_2\left(1-\beta_1\beta_2\right). \label{eq:gammar}\tag{2}\\
&\text{The windward plate is perpendicular to the motion, hence } S' = S. \label{eq:S} \tag{3}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 2
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{J^\mu=(n c,\; n v_x,\; n v_y,\; n v_z)\quad\text{(number 4-current in a given frame)}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Lorentz boost along }x:\ \ J'^0=\gamma_1\big(J^0-\beta_1 J^x\big),\ \ J'^x=\gamma_1\big(J^x-\beta_1 J^0\big)}\]
\[\boxed{n'=\dfrac{J'^0}{c}\quad\text{(number density in the boosted frame)}}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{In S, the dust 4-current is } J^\mu=(n c,\; n v_2,\; 0,\; 0).\label{eq:J}\tag{4}\\
&\text{Boost to S′ with speed }v_1\text{ along }+x:\nonumber\\
J'^0&=\gamma_1\left(J^0-\beta_1 J^x\right)
=\gamma_1\left(n c-\beta_1\, n v_2\right)
=\gamma_1\,n c\,\left(1-\beta_1\beta_2\right). \label{eq:J0}\tag{5}\\
\Rightarrow\quad
n'&=\frac{J'^0}{c}=\gamma_1\,n\,\left(1-\beta_1\beta_2\right). \label{eq:nprime}\tag{6}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 3
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\mathbf{p}=\gamma m \mathbf{v}\quad\text{(relativistic momentum)}}\]
\[\boxed{\text{Elastic reflection from an immovable wall in its rest frame: }E'_{\text{after}}=E'_{\text{before}},\ \ p'_{x,\text{after}}=-p'_{x,\text{before}}}\]
\[\boxed{F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}\ \ \text{(force as rate of momentum change in a given frame)}}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{In S′, an incoming dust particle has }p'_x=\gamma' m v' \ (\text{with }v'<0).\label{eq:px}\tag{7}\\
&\text{Elastic reflection at the windward plate (rest in S′): }p'_{x,\text{after}}=-p'_{x,\text{before}}.\nonumber\\
&\text{Thus the particle’s momentum change is }\Delta p'_{\text{particle}}=-2\,p'_x.\label{eq:dp_particle}\tag{8}\\
&\text{By momentum conservation, the impulse delivered to the plate (spaceship) per collision is }\nonumber\\
\Delta p'_{\text{ship}}&=-\Delta p'_{\text{particle}}=2\,|p'_x|=2\,\gamma' m |v'|. \label{eq:impulse}\tag{9}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 4
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\dot N'_{\text{hit}}=n'\,S\,|v'|\quad\text{(particle flux onto a surface normal to motion in S′)}}\]
\[\boxed{F'_{\text{drag}}=\dot N'_{\text{hit}}\times (\text{impulse per collision})}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
\dot N'_{\text{hit}}&=n'\,S\,|v'|\quad\text{(number of dust impacts per unit time in S′)}. \label{eq:rate}\tag{10}\\
F'_{\text{drag}}&=\dot N'_{\text{hit}}\times \Delta p'_{\text{ship}}
=\big(n' S |v'|\big)\,\big(2\,\gamma' m |v'|\big)\nonumber\\
&=2\,n' S\,m\,\gamma'\,v'^2. \label{eq:Fdrag}\tag{11}\\
&\text{Insert }n' \text{ from \eqref{eq:nprime}, }\gamma' \text{ from \eqref{eq:gammar}, and }v' \text{ from \eqref{eq:vprime}:}\nonumber\\
F'_{\text{drag}}
&=2\,\big[\gamma_1 n (1-\beta_1\beta_2)\big]\,S\,m\,\big[\gamma_1\gamma_2(1-\beta_1\beta_2)\big]\,
\left(\frac{v_2-v_1}{1-\dfrac{v_1 v_2}{c^2}}\right)^2 \nonumber\\
&=2\,n S m\,\gamma_1^2\gamma_2\,(1-\beta_1\beta_2)^2\,
\frac{(v_1-v_2)^2}{\left(1-\dfrac{v_1 v_2}{c^2}\right)^2}\nonumber\\
&=2\,n S m\,\gamma_1^2\gamma_2\,(v_1-v_2)^2. \label{eq:Fdragfinal}\tag{12}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 5
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{E_\gamma=h\,u_0,\quad p_\gamma=\frac{E_\gamma}{c}=\frac{h u_0}{c}\quad\text{(photon energy–momentum)}}\]
\[\boxed{F=\frac{dp}{dt}\ \ \Rightarrow\ \ F'_{\text{thrust}}=\left(\frac{h u_0}{c}\right)N'\ \ \text{for colinear photon emission in S′}}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
&\text{In S′, each photon emitted directly backward has momentum magnitude }p_\gamma=\frac{h u_0}{c}. \label{eq:pgamma}\tag{13}\\
&\text{Emitting }N'\text{ photons per unit time (in S′) produces a backward momentum flux }N'\frac{h u_0}{c}.\nonumber\\
&\text{By reaction, the ship gains forward thrust }F'_{\text{thrust}}=\left(\frac{h u_0}{c}\right)N'. \label{eq:Fthrust}\tag{14}
\end{align}
\]

### Step 6
Principles/Original Formulas/Assumptions
\[\boxed{\text{Constant speed requires zero net 3-force in the instantaneous rest frame: }F'_{\text{thrust}}=F'_{\text{drag}}}\]

Derivation
\[
\begin{align}
F'_{\text{thrust}}&=F'_{\text{drag}} \quad\Rightarrow\quad
\left(\frac{h u_0}{c}\right)N'=2\,n S m\,\gamma_1^2\gamma_2\,(v_1-v_2)^2 \quad \text{(by \eqref{eq:Fdragfinal}, \eqref{eq:Fthrust})}\nonumber\\
\Rightarrow\quad
N'&=\frac{2\,n\,S\,m\,c\,\gamma_1^{2}\,\gamma_2\,\big(v_1-v_2\big)^2}{h\,u_0}. \label{eq:Nprime}\tag{15}
\end{align}
\]

### Final Answer
\[
\begin{align}
\boxed{\,N'=\dfrac{2\,n\,S\,m\,c\,\gamma_1^{2}\,\gamma_2\,\big(v_1-v_2\big)^2}{h\,u_0}\,}
\end{align}
\]

Consider a non-ideal gas system. Without worrying about the internal composition and interaction details, we find that its macroscopic equation of state is:

$$
p = k V^{-4/5}T^{3/2}
$$

where $k$ is a constant coefficient.

Consider a very special case. If for this non-ideal gas, its specific heat ratio:

$$
\gamma = \frac{C_{p}}{C_{V}}
$$

is exactly a constant that is independent of temperature and volume. Calculate the value of $\gamma$.
solutions:
Combine the formula for the difference in heat capacities with the heat capacity relation:

$$
C_{p}=\gamma C_{V}
$$

This directly solves for the heat capacity:

$$
C_{V}=\frac{45}{16}\frac{k V^{1/5}T^{1/2}}{\gamma-1}
$$

And at this point, it must satisfy

$$
\frac{\partial C_{V}}{\partial V}=g=\frac{3}{4}k V^{-4/5}T^{1/2}
$$

Substituting gives the only possible value for $\gamma$:

$$
\gamma=\frac{7}{4}
$$
